This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Dear listener, we feel your pain, especially today if you're one of the millions and millions and millions of Americans traveling a long way to see your family.
And you know, once you get there, it's usually not a Norman Rockwell theme.
More like Noah Baumbach.
He is the filmmaker who specializes in dysfunctional family movies.
Two years ago, he made ""The Squid and the Whale."" And now his new movie is out.
It's ""Margot at the Wedding."" And Madeleine, this is what you discussed when you spoke with him yesterday.
Noah Baumbach, welcome to DAY TO DAY.
Thank you.
This story, your movie, it's about a dysfunctional family.
And you know, I don't want to do the encapsulation and say what the movie is about, since you're here and you can do it a lot better.
So...
I was actually - was hoping you would do it because I'm the worst person at describing the movie.
It's about a mother and her son who travel from their home in New York to the country to visit the mom's sister, who is about to get married to a man that Margot, the mother, has never met before.
And sort of a reunion of sorts and how, I suppose, ultimately you can't escape your family.
That's sort of how I think of the movie in a generalized way.
And the mother is played by Nicole Kidman.
The son, he's 12 years old?
Twelve years old when we shot, yeah.
An actor named Zane Pais.
And so he's on the brink of adolescence.
And I just want to play a clip from the movie, a scene between the two of them.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Margot at the Wedding"")
(As Margot) I hope you're not interested in that girl.
I think she's insufferable.
(As Claude) What does that mean?
(As Margot) It means I can't suffer her.
She's loud and stupid, and she goes on about things that she knows nothing about.
(As Claude) She got into Harvard early.
(As Margot) Stupid people get into Harvard early all the time.
So there you have not a traditional conversation, I would imagine, between a mother and son, a son that's 12 years old, and she sort of talks to him like he's a grown-up...
Mm-hmm.
...in a kind of neurotic way.
And I'm just wondering how you wrote that scene and what you were thinking of in terms of describing this particular relationship.

Well, I do think it's interesting how adults often treat children like confidants or equals when it suits them or when - I think often when they're going through crisis or something, if the child is the person nearest to them, that they kind of bring them with them.
So I suppose in a lot of ways I don't write it any differently than I write anything else.
I mean, it just seemed like this is the way these characters spoke.
Mm-hmm.
A lot of the reviews I've ever had had described the two main characters - the two sisters, Margot and Pauline, as dislikable characters.
Mm-hmm.
As people you don't really want to spend a lot of time with in real life.
And I'm wondering, do you agree with that assessment?
Not at all.
I mean, I think these are people I recognize from the world, and I guess I'm surprised in some cases that some people don't recognize these people.
I think, in a way, it's a way to talk about sympathy or where, you know, is somebody sympathetic or unsympathetic.
For me it's just not interesting in terms of approaching a movie, I mean as a moviegoer and has a moviemaker.
I mean, what's interesting is that people are understandable and interesting to watch.
I mean, obviously in a popcorn that might be the proper criteria to bring in.
But to force your own expectations based on what you think a movie should be, in a movie like this I just don't think that's the right way to look at the film.
Uh-huh.
Well, speaking of appending your expectations, Jack Black in this movie.

Right.

Yeah.

We can finally lay to rest this rumor.
For a decade, a story has circulated about Tommy Hilfiger.

Hilfiger allegedly appeared on ""Oprah"" years ago and as the story goes, he said he would not have made his clothes so nice if he had known they would be popular among African-Americans, Asians, Hispanics and Jews.
Well, with that, Oprah is alleged to have booted him off the show and canned the segment.
So Hilfiger really did appear on ""Oprah"" yesterday for the first time, and together, they put the rumor to rest.
Not true, he said, adding that he had hired investigators to track down just how that rumor got started.
